Dear Ms. Williams:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
07/03/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective aciton plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Tyler Armstrong, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time
between the variable interval checks shall not exceed
fifteen minutes.
A random sample of bed check logs showed that staff were not performing eyes-
on checks of youth within variable fifteen minute intervals.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided regarding proper documentation of initial health
screenings of youth being admitted to the facility from the other residential programs
within the overall organization. Technical assistance was also provided regarding the
intentional and clear inclusion of necessary narratives in discharge planning.
2

V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was provided in the area of ensuring proper documentation from the
facility's other programs is located in this program's file.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: Two
corrective action plans were approved during this reporting period, both the results
of special investigations. SIR #2025SIC0000390 produced a CAP related to rule
violations for staff using inappropriate language towards youth. The CAP included
action steps for the staff being involved having their employment terminated and
re-training of remaining staff on facility policy regarding the treatment of youth.
Staff were all trained as required on the CAP and no follow up concerns have
been found. SIR #2025SIC0000420 produced a CAP related to the same rule
violation. The CAP contained similar action items.
Financial Overview
The organization’s most recent financial audit for 2023 and a current budget was
reviewed, and no concerns were noted about the organization.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The annual Chief Administrator assessment was completed on 06/30/2025. The
Chief Administrator discussed an influx of newly hired staff, contractual changes
that resulted in programming changes, successful discharges with only one being
unplanned and the facility restraint reduction efforts.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face visit on 07/03/2025.
Staff reported positive experiences working at the program. They felt supported by
management to "run" the house in the ways that best benefitted the youth in the
3

program. They also felt that the milieu of the program allowed them to get to know
the youth well.
Youth were interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face visit on 07/03/2025.
Youth reported positive experiences at the program overall. They felt that the
communication within the program was adequate, and their personal needs were
met well. Struggles were noted with the smaller size of the census of the program
and the frequency with which decisions about safety from staff regarding youth
would cause activities or outings to be difficult to implement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility house was toured during an unannounced, face-to-face visit on
07/03/2025. No safety concerns were noted. It was in clean and organized
condition and there were ample supplies and groceries.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
